simulated_ratings.feeling: Epic, methodical cat-and-mouse crime saga that hits all my buttons

simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody, personal conspiracy thriller that keeps me engaged

simulated_ratings.title: Murder by Decree (1979)

simulated_ratings.title: Seven Blessings (2023)

simulated_ratings.title: Kill Bill: Vol. 2 (2004)

simulated_ratings.title: Mystic River (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleak, morally thorny and haunting - right in my wheelhouse

simulated_ratings.title: CM Punk: Best in the World (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Solid behind-the-curtain doc, though the subject only mildly interests me

recommended_movies: NY77: The Coolest Year in Hell (2007)
Things to Do in Denver When You're Dead (1995)
Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

simulated_ratings.title: Rent (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Energetic and heartfelt, but the sentimentality and stagey flourishes blunt it for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Moulin Rouge (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dizzying style and big feeling, though the overload keeps me admiring more than moved.

simulated_ratings.title: Saw (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grimy, nasty little survival tale with a hook that works even if the gimmick looms large.

simulated_ratings.title: Summer of Sam (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Paranoia, heat and neighborhood tensions make for a messy but compelling urban fever dream.

simulated_ratings.title: Dumb & Dumber (Dumb and Dumber) (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Frequently funny in its idiocy, even if the lowbrow antics wear thin.

simulated_ratings.title: NY77: The Coolest Year in Hell (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Vivid, gritty snapshot of a city in collapse and rebirth—right in my wheelhouse.

simulated_ratings.title: Saw (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tense, nasty, cleverly boxed-in thriller whose moral game kept me engaged despite the sadism.

simulated_ratings.title: A sangre fría (1959)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Fatalistic crime spiral with a classic noir pull, even if time has dulled some edges.

simulated_ratings.title: Hanappe Bazooka (1992)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Raunchy, juvenile chaos that’s more off-putting than fun for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Things to Do in Denver When You're Dead (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Talky, stylish neo-noir with a doomed-romantic streak that mostly works.

simulated_ratings.title: God Said 'Ha!' (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Wry, candid monologue that finds honest humor in hard times, modest but affecting.

simulated_ratings.title: The Fault in Our Stars (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sincere and polished, but the tear-duct prodding feels too calculated for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Cecil B. DeMented (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Anarchic movie-mad satire with sparks of fun, scattershot in impact.

simulated_ratings.title: Mars Attacks! (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Goofy, gaudy sci-fi lampoon that amuses in bursts more than it lands as a whole.

simulated_ratings.title: Life, Autumn (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quiet, humane observation with a melancholic pull, a bit too slight to linger.

simulated_ratings.title: Invincible Shaolin (1978)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Crisp training-and-revenge rhythms deliver, even if the drama stays broad.

simulated_ratings.title: Umbrella Coup (1980)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A breezy mistaken-identity crime farce with a sharp hook and easy charm.

simulated_ratings.title: Ex-Shaman (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A stark, empathetic look at cultural erosion that sticks without preaching.

simulated_ratings.title: The Infinite Man (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever, tight time-loop romance whose obsessive mechanics I enjoyed.

simulated_ratings.title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Zippy, witty and visually inventive family fun that actually sticks.

simulated_ratings.title: Ricochet (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Serviceable Southern-fried potboiler with enough twisty intrigue to pass.

simulated_ratings.title: Lonely Castle in the Mirror (2022)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gentle, empathetic fairy-tale mystery that’s nice more than gripping for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Children of the Corn (1984)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Great premise, middling execution—creepy idea that fades fast.

simulated_ratings.title: Karlson Returns (1970)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Light, amicable family antics that go down easy and drift away.

simulated_ratings.title: Bob Roberts (1992)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Smart, sharp-edged political satire that scratches my cynical itch.

simulated_ratings.title: Zoolander (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Affably dumb and quotable, funny in spurts and featherweight overall.

simulated_ratings.title: Maestro (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A neat little animated twist that entertains and evaporates.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Sweet, imaginative appliance odyssey that’s pleasant more than gripping.

simulated_ratings.title: Winnie Pooh (1969)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A gentle, honey-seeking lark that’s charming and slight for me.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Retro space-rescue adventure that hits my sci-fi sweet spot even if the drama stays broad.

simulated_ratings.title: Wings of Desire (Himmel über Berlin, Der) (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lyrical, humane meditation on longing that I admire and can sink into.

simulated_ratings.title: Rugrats Movie, The (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bright, kid-marketed antics that go down easy and fade fast for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Urbania (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody urban-legend noir with a haunted core that pulls me in.

simulated_ratings.title: Rugrats Go Wild! (2003)

simulated_ratings.title: Real Life (1979)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sharp, prickly media satire that scratches my cynical itch.

simulated_ratings.title: Love Is Blind (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quiet, sad small-town tale that interests more than it moves me.

simulated_ratings.title: Love Stories in Sunflower Valley (2021)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A cheery, prefab Hallmark homecoming I can’t really invest in.

simulated_ratings.title: Wallace and Gromit in 'A Matter of Loaf and Death' (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever, zippy clay caper with a playful murder-mystery bite.

simulated_ratings.title: Missing Picture, The (L'image manquante) (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Inventive, harrowing historical reckoning that sticks with me.

simulated_ratings.title: Thin Red Line, The (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lyrical war poetry that haunts in moments, even as the remove keeps me at bay.

simulated_ratings.title: Everything Will Be OK (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleakly funny, existential spiral that lingers more than most shorts.

simulated_ratings.title: Looking: The Movie (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Low-key relationship roundelay with some insight and modest impact.

simulated_ratings.title: Drive My Car (2021)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Patient, intimate grief study whose quiet revelations pay off.

simulated_ratings.title: Romance (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Provocative and raw, but the confrontational sex-as-catharsis approach leaves me cold.

simulated_ratings.title: In the Company of Men (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cold-blooded, razor-edged cruelty tale that hits where it hurts.

simulated_ratings.title: We are the tide (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody, intriguing sci-fi mystery whose hook may outpace its payoff for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Three Colors: White (Trzy kolory: Bialy) (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dry, ironic little revenge-and-reinvention tale that works more in tone than heat for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Monster, The (Mostro, Il) (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Broad mistaken-identity farce that amuses in spots and evaporates.

simulated_ratings.title: Breakdown (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lean, relentless abduction thriller with the no-nonsense momentum I crave.

simulated_ratings.title: Roma (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gorgeous, empathetic slice of life I admire, even if the restraint keeps me a bit detached.

simulated_ratings.title: Bill Burr: I'm Sorry You Feel That Way (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Acerbic, unfiltered stand-up that consistently hits my cynical sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: The Passion of the Mao (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Flip, hagiographic gloss that plays like propaganda more than insight.

simulated_ratings.title: Manhattan Romance (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Talky, self-reflective NYC relationship stew that goes down easy without cutting deep.

recommended_movies: In a Glass Cage (Tras el cristal) (1986)
Halloween III: Season of the Witch (1982)
The Untold Story of Emmett Louis Till (2005)
The Wild World of Lydia Lunch (1983)

simulated_ratings.title: Party Girl (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Breezy downtown charm and a self-reckoning arc that entertains even if it skims the surface.

simulated_ratings.title: In a Glass Cage (Tras el cristal) (1986)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A suffocating, morally poisonous chamber piece that disturbs and grips me.

simulated_ratings.title: Frighteners, The (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever ghost-con hustle and effects-driven antics that amuse while the tone wobbles.

simulated_ratings.title: Kaamelott - The First Chapter (2021)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Playful medieval shenanigans that feel loose without my attachment to the series.

simulated_ratings.title: Fatherland (1986)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cold-war disillusionment and identity games I can sink into, even if it keeps a cool distance.

simulated_ratings.title: An Actor Prepares (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Caustic father-son road bickering that goes down easy on a very familiar arc.

simulated_ratings.title: House of the Spirits, The (1993)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A sweeping, turbulent family saga I admire more than I feel.

simulated_ratings.title: The Last Great Wilderness (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: An offbeat detour into culty menace with enough atmosphere to keep me hooked.

simulated_ratings.title: There's Always Tomorrow (1956)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A crisp, bittersweet midcentury temptation tale that lands with an adult sting.

simulated_ratings.title: Tigger Movie, The (2000)

simulated_ratings.title: American Sniper (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tense and polished on the ground, but its perspective keeps me at arm's length.

simulated_ratings.title: Big Wednesday (1978)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Laid-back surf-bro drift that charms in pockets and mostly glides by.

simulated_ratings.title: Dr. Horrible's Sing-Along Blog (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Snarky, tuneful villainy with a bittersweet sting—smart, slight, and fun.

simulated_ratings.title: Reefer Madness (a.k.a. Tell Your Children) (1938)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Hysterical propaganda that plays best as campy artifact, not drama.

simulated_ratings.title: Night of the Living Dead (1968)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A stark, claustrophobic siege that still crawls under my skin.

simulated_ratings.title: Halloween III: Season of the Witch (1982)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Weird, nasty standalone with a great hook that works unevenly.

simulated_ratings.title: The Voyeur (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Glossy erotic obsession that titillates more than it cuts, leaving me cold.

simulated_ratings.title: Zapped (2014)

simulated_ratings.title: The Untold Story of Emmett Louis Till (2005)

simulated_ratings.title: Trigun: Badlands Rumble (2010)

simulated_ratings.title: The Wild World of Lydia Lunch (1983)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A grimy, intimate snapshot that intrigues even as it stays insular.

simulated_ratings.title: Tod Browning's 'Freaks': The Sideshow Cinema (2004)

simulated_ratings.title: Suck Me Shakespeer 3 (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Broad, rowdy classroom antics with enough energy to pass the time.

simulated_ratings.title: Csontvary (1980)
simulated_ratings.feeling: An austere artist portrait I respect more than I connect with.

simulated_ratings.title: I Want to Live! (1958)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A tense, compassionate death-row spiral that hits my crime-drama sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: Skinner (1993)
